occurrences.line_text: And take away this long lent loathed light:
That long captiued soules from wearie thraldome free.
Long maist thou liue, and better thriue withall,
Or hold sad life in long captiuitee:
So long as heauens iust with equall brow
So long they traueiled with litle ease,
And weened well ere long his will to win,
As fearefull fowle, that long in secret caue
Shakt his long lockes, colourd like copper-wire,
In which we long time without gealous feares,
Long I her seru'd, and found her faithfull still,
Assur'd, ere long the truth to let me vnderstand.
Ere long with like againe he boorded mee,
Through woods and plaines so long I did her chace,
After that varlets flight, it was not long,
His sandy lockes, long hanging downe behind,
It was not long, ere she inflam'd him so,
(That day it selfe him seemed all too long:)
A long the shore, as swift as glaunce of eye,
Him needed not long call, she soone to hond
Disdeigning to be held so long in fight;
The maisters of his long experiment,
So long he yode, yet no aduenture found,
Long were to tell the troublous stormes, that tosse
Well hoped he, ere long that hardy guest,
And grieu'd, so long to lacke his greedy pray;
To catchen hold of that long chaine, thereby
Whom he had long time sought with fruitlesse suit:
He there beheld, too long here to be told:
Ne Mammon would there let him long remaine,
And now he has so long remained there,
Till him the child bespoke, Long lackt, alas,
For life ere long shall to her home retire,
The guilt, which if he liued had thus long,
Then like a Lion, which hath long time saught
Long trembling still he stood: at last thus sayd;
But when the Palmer, whom he long ygoe
I long haue lackt, I ioy thy face to vew;
They found the gates fast barred long ere night,
And with long siege vs in this castle hould:
Some with vnweldy clubs, some with long speares,
Neither vnseemely short, nor yet exceeding long.
And one great chimney, whose long tonnell thence,
So long as any thing it in the caudron got.
In a long purple pall, whose skirt with gold,
So long as Guyon with her commoned,
Who did them meditate all his life long,
Ne suffred them to perish through long eld,
Some made in books, some in long parchme[n]t scrolles,
Polluted this same gentle soyle long time:
And raigned long in great felicitie,
His life, and long good fortune vnto finall fate.
His sonne king Leill by fathers labour long,
Next him king Leyr in happie peace long raind,
With Gonorill, long had in great renowne,
Who peaceably the same long time did weld:
And ouercommen kept in prison long,
In wretched prison long he did remaine,
And ruled long with honorable state,
And goodly well long time it gouerned,
Yet true it is, that long before that day
Who after long debate, since Lucies time,
Long time in peace his Realme established,
That in the Realme ere long they stronger arre,
The crowne, which Vortiger did long detaine:
And wonder of antiquitie long stopt his speach.
My leasure, so long leaues here to repeat:
That were too long their infinite contents
Long mayst thou Glorian liue, in glory and great powre.
So long they red in those antiquities,
To thinke, how supper did them long awaite.
Ere long they rowed were quite out of sight,
And the sad husbandmans long hope doth throw
Whiles his long legs nigh raught vnto the ground;
As one awakt out of long slombring shade,
Hath long bene vnderkept, and downe supprest,
Amid th'AegÃ¦an sea long time did stray,
Ere long they heard an hideous bellowing
Which flowing long and thick, her cloth'd arownd,
In secret shade, after long wanton ioyes:
After long wayes and perilous paines endured,
Because of trauell long, a nigher way,
Long so they trauelled through wastefull wayes,
To loose long gotten honour with one euill hond.
Long they thus trauelled in friendly wise,
Full griesly seem'd: therein they long did ryde,
Long were it to describe the goodly frame,
Who through a Chamber long and spacious,
Long worke it were, and needlesse to deuize
And by long triall of the inward griefe,
Eftsoones long waxen torches weren light,
Where through long watch, & late dayes weary toile,
T'abridg their iourney long, and lingring day;
Wherein th'ï¿½gyptian Phao long did lurke
That through long languour, and hart-burning brame
Which long hath waited by the Stygian strond.
Till that by dew degrees and long pretence,
Which thousand sprights with long enduring paines
Whom long he lou'd, for him in hast did send,
The feeble Britons, broken with long warre,
Long time ye both in armes shall beare great sway,
Hath long time slept, himselfe so shall he shake,
Yet shall he long time warre with happy speed,
From their long vassalage gin to respire,
From Armoricke, where long in wretched cace
Will not long misery late mercy make,
For his great vertues proued long afore:
Long followed, but not fond.
For all too long I burne with enuy sore,
Wherein my feeble barke is tossed long,
Long time she fostred vp, till he became
To the long raynes, at her commaundement:
And full of fiery zeale, him followed long,
So long that now the golden Hesperus
Of his long labour, he gan fowly wyte
And bring with him his long expected light?
And chase away this too long lingring night,
Who long time wandred through the forrest wyde,
For Ladies loue his mother long ygoe
To that faire Damzell: Him he chaced long
But labour'd long in that deepe ford with vaine disease.
And still the foster with his long bore-speare
Long while he stroue in his courageous brest,
Thus warreid he long time against his will,
Where wearie of long trauell, downe to rest
So may he long himselfe full easie hide:
So long they sought, till they arriued were
According to their kindes. Long worke it were,
After long troubles and vnmeet vpbrayes,
Long after she from perill was releast:
So long as breath, and hable puissance
But nought that wanteth rest, can long aby.
So long she trauelled, till at length she came
So stared he on her, and stood long while amazed.
Now well recouered after long repast,
But greedily long gaping at the sight,
So long he held him, and him bet so long,
So long he held him, and him bet so long,
As he had long bene learned to obay;
Out of his dreame, that did him long entraunce,
After she long in waite for me did lye,
After long suit and weary seruicis,
Long thus I woo'd her with dew obseruance,
Or long enlargement of her painefull smart.
Quite of all hope, wherewith he long had fed
His foolish maladie, and long time had misled.
She was the Lady selfe, whom he so long had sought.
Him long she so with shadowes entertained,
Thus as they two of kindnesse treated long,
Long so she on the mightie maine did flote,
And the wide sea importuned long space
Had long while laboured it to engraue:
A long discourse of his aduentures vaine,
Ne long shall Satyrane behind you stay,
And now so long before the wicket fast
Which in th'earthes hollow caues hath long bin hid,
That in a cloud their light did long time stay,
Who long before the ten yeares siege of Troy,
Where he through fatall errour long was led
And in long Alba plast his throne apart,
Where faire it florished, and long time it stoud,
Where wearie wandring they long time did wonne,
And great adue[n]tures found, that now were lo[n]g to sayne.
Whom he through wearie wars and labours long,
So long these knights discoursed diuersly,
Which th'old man seeing well, who too long thought
And his faire wife, whom honest long he kept vneath.
Or daily siege through dispuruayance long,
Long thus he chawd the cud of inward griefe,
Long he her sought, he sought her farre and nere,
Then sighing sore, It is not long (said he)
I sweare, ere long shall dearely it repent;
Thus long they three together traueiled,
The greene-wood long did walke, and wander wide
But through long anguish, and selfe-murdring thought
Whence he with crooked clawes so long did crall,
Where in her bosome she thee long had nurst,
And hatefull outrage long him chaced thus;
For he was long, and swift as any Roe,
Faire Britomart so long him followed,
So long vnwreaked of thine enimy?
Through the greene gras his long bright burnisht backe declares.
Long were to tell each other louely fit,
They trembling stood, and made a long broad dyke,
Long were to tell the amorous assayes,
And a long bloudy riuer through them rayld,
Her greedy eyes with gazing a long space:
Not caring his long labours to deface,
With that great chaine, wherewith not long ygo
But he sad man, when he had long in drede
Whose too long absence him had sore annoyd,
In the coole soile, after long thirstinesse,
But like two senceles stocks in long embraceme[n]t dwelt.
And ye faire swayns, after your long turmoyle,
Long wandred they, yet neuer met with none,
Of fatall Thebes, of Rome that raigned long,
That were too long a worke to count them all;
And much vnlike, th'one long, the other short,
Till that ere long they chaunced to espie
And mounting light his foe for lying long vpbrayes.
Too boastfull Blandamour, too long I beare
Long may you liue in health and happie state.
Ne certes can that friendship long endure,
That stroue in vaine him long to haue withstood,
Which she with her long fostred in that wood,
To know, and them t'enlarge with long extent,
doth their long strife agree.
Long life, thereby did more prolong their paine.
Haue I thus long thy life vnto thee let:
Till Diamond disdeigning long delay
Through hunger long, that hart to him doth lend,
Stand vp so long, and weapon vaine to weld,
And that he should not long on foote endure,
Long while they then continued in that wize,
That life it selfe seemd loathsome, and long safetie ill.
They had as then her long to entertaine.)
With whom he ledd a long and happie life;
Against the Turneiment which is not long.
Where in a maze they both did long remaine,
Out of the swowne, in which too long he lay;
And bad them leaue their labours and long toyle,
Her claym'd, by him in battell wonne long sens:
Then when she long had lookt vpon each one,
Who likewise sought her louer long miswent,
As if he had in prison long bene pent:
And fingers filthie, with long nayles vnpared,
And hauing long beheld, at last enquired
After so long a trauell, which them both did tire.
There lay Sir Scudamour long while expecting,
And then lay musing long, on that him ill apayd.
So long he muzed, and so long he lay,
So long he muzed, and so long he lay,
Long time resist, gaue place to kindly rest,
He all that night, that too long night did passe.
Shall breath it selfe awhile, after so long a went.
The which ere long full deare he shall abie.
Whiles with long fight on foot he breathlesse was,
He through long sufferance growing now more great,
Thus long they trac'd, and trauerst to and fro,
And he himselfe long gazing thereupon,
All that long while vpheld her wrathfull hand,
Ioyous to see her safe after long toyle.
Long since in that enchaunted glasse she saw.
The which long time his grieued hart did wound,
Where she captiued long, great woes did proue;
Tho when they had long time there taken rest,
To follow that, which he did long propound;
Were long to tell; therefore I here will stay
With which their liues thou lanchedst long afore,
They trauel'd long, that now for wearinesse,
Of Britomart after long tedious toyle,
And downe both sides two wide long eares did glow,
Which she long listning, softly askt againe
Long so she fled, and so he follow'd long;
Long so she fled, and so he follow'd long;
Yet ouer him she there long gazing stood,
At last when long he follow'd had in vaine,
And through long fasting woxen pale and wan,
Tho when he long had marked his demeanor,
Which for it is too long here to abide,
Thus long this gentle bird to him did vse,
Companion she became, and so continued long.
And looking after long, did marke which way she straid.
But when as long he looked had in vaine,
His sodaine silence, which he long had pent,
In which he long time afterwards did lead
Vnto the earth, and lay long while in senselesse swowne.
Yet as it was, it did astonish him long space.
I thether went where I did long conceale
As was my friend, that had her long refusd,
But what mishap thus long him fro my selfe remoues?
In which so long he mercilesse did lie.
Who now long time had lyen in prison sad,
Thus gazing long, at them much wondred he,
They liu'd together long without debate:
And seeking long, to weet which way she straid
Thus they long while continued in fight,
Long here and there, and round about doth stie,
From such foule outrage, and them long forbore:
Long were to tell the trauell and long toile,
Long were to tell the trauell and long toile,
Or that in Cyprus, both long since this same,
All twenty tride in warres experience long;
Long languishing there in vnpittied paine,
And costly frame, were long here to relate.
Bvt ah for pittie that I haue thus long
In which he long time after did remaine
Long had the Thames (as we in records reed)
The rich Cteatus, and Eurytus long;
Long Rhodanus, whose sourse springs from the skie;
Ioy on those warlike women, which so long
But past not long, ere Brutus warlicke sonne
And following Dee, which Britons long ygone
All which long sundred, doe at last accord
All goodly damzels, deckt with long greene haire,
Whose names and nations were too long to tell,
In which I daily dying am too long.
Gainst womens loue, long giuen him in vaine.
And daunger well he wist long to continue there.
Which him had sought through trouble & lo[n]g strife;
Ere long so weake of limbe, and sicke of loue
As that, through long continuance of his course,
They into that ere long will be degendered.
That hence so long departed, is but vaine:
It was not long, before he ouertooke
The fortune of her life long time did feare.
Which is but narrow, but exceeding long;
There they together stroue and struggled long,
Long they her sought, yet no where could they finde her,
We are not sure they would so long remaine:
Might not it peise; yet did he labour long,
Long wayted, saw his sudden desolation,
A Fter long stormes and tempests ouerblowne,
After long sorrowes suffered whyleare,
But he ere long the former fiftie bet;
He long astonisht stood, ne ought he sayd,
Of rude obliuion, and long times decay,
Which long agoe he taken had in hond:
Twixt life and death, long to and fro she weaued,
After long tossing in the seas distrest,
Ere long their Queene her selfe, halfe like a man
Into a long large chamber, which was sield
Thus there long while continu'd Artegall,
Which long concealing in her couert brest,
At last when long she struggled had in vaine,
To thinke how this long death thou mightest disinherit.
That she therefore would him ere long forestall.
Great shame to lose so long employed paines,
Thus he long while in thraldome there remayned,
One day, when as she long had sought for ease
There as she looked long, at last she spide
Her selfe there close afflicted long in vaine,
It was not long, before she heard the sound
And on their heads with long locks comely kemd,
And thereuppon long while stood gazing still,
She stretched forth a long white sclender wand.
Had long beheld, her selfe vppon the land
After that long daies toile and weary plight.
So thereuppon long while she musing lay,
And with long locks vp-standing, stifly stared
The end whereof, and all the long euent,
Had long surceast, she bad to open bold,
Who long before awoke (for she ful ill
So long they fought, that all the grassie flore
And dead long since in dolorous distresse,
After long trauell of full twenty yeares,
But stood long staring on him, mongst vncertaine feares.
Which they had long vsurpt; and them restoring
For all those Knights, which long in captiue shade
His horses backe, yet to and fro long shooke,
So long as in his steedes the flaming breath did last.
Thus long they trast, and trauerst to and fro,
And roiall pompe, which there long hidden lay,
So both for rest there hauing stayd not long,
And long curld locks, that downe his shoulders shagged,
And in his hand an huge long staffe he held,
But he then stones at it so long did cast,
Whose long rest rusted the bright steely brand;
Which long he vsd with carefull diligence,
It was not long, till that the Prince arriued
Stryuing long time in vaine it to withstond;
Long sought the Prince, but when he found no more
That right long time is ouerborne of wrong,
As by sad Belge seemes, whose wrongs though long
So long had done, and from her natiue land
That stretcht it selfe, as it had long lyen still;
And her long taile and fethers strongly shooke,
To loose his shield, and long while did contend:
Tho with her huge long taile she at him strooke,
On which long way he rode, ne euer day did rest.
Who through his yeares long since aside had set
But now aread, Sir Sergis, how long space,
To him for aide, who long in vaine their rage withstands.
Gainst whom my selfe I long in vaine haue bent,
Stood long amaz'd, as she amated weare.
No loue so lasting then, that may enduren long.
Gainst whom Sir Artegall, long hauing since
Whose steale was yron studded, but not long,
Long while he tug'd and stroue, to get it out,
Which with strong powre did them long time oppresse;
In all her life, with long nayles ouer raught,
As if that long she had not eaten ought;
Bit him behind, that long the marke was to be read.
And by them long with carefull labour nurst,
In perils strange, in labours long and wide;
Where he was fostred long in Stygian fen,
Sir Calidore thence trauelled not long,
And it hath long mayntaind with mighty wrong:
She long time hath deare lou'd a doughty Knight,
Him long forbore, and still his spirite spar'd,
And long restrayned of his ready course;
With his long taile the bryzes brush away.
Where long he stayed not, when as a Knight
Thus long they trac'd and trauerst to and fro,
So long as these two armes were able to be wroken.
Assayld, not knowing what to armes doth long.
She hidden was, and sought her so long, as him list.
After long search and chauff, he turned backe
Stroue to appease him, and perswaded long:
And when he long had him beholding stood,
Into this land, where I haue wond thus long,
Long shut vp in the bud from heauens vew,
Thus when they long had treated to and fro,
Long fed his greedie eyes with the faire sight
And powring balme, which he had long puruayd,
Which I expected long, now turnd to sad annoy?
Of so long waies to him befallen late.
His long aduentures gan to him relate,
In trauelling on foote so long a space,
So that at length, after long weary chace,
He ouer raught him, hauing long eschew'd
Like as a ship with dreadfull storme long tost,
Long did he wrest and wring it to and fro,
Who hauing now no vse of his long speare,
So as ere long he had that knightes wound
For hauing long time, as his daily weed,
Ere long he ouertooke, and forst to stay,
Ere long enforst to breath his vtmost blast,
For which he long in vaine did sweat and swinke,
Who when as now long time he lacked had
There she long groueling, and deepe groning lay,
His steede now strong through rest so long a space,
Full like ere long to haue escaped hard;
Why haue ye me alone thus long yleft?
Hath you thus long away from me bereft?
Where I had surely long ere this bene dead,
So long as age enabled him thereto,
And through the long experience of his dayes,
And you faire sonne, which here thus long now lie
And long in darksome Stygian den vpbrought,
Ere long to him a homely groome there came,
As if he long had to his heasts bene trayned.
Ere long they came, whereas in euill tyde
Did languish long in lifeconsuming smart,
To seeke for safety, which long time she sought:
At last the caytiue after long discourse,
Thus I triumphed long in louers paine,
Long thus she fled, till that at last she thought
Of her long trauell and turmoyling paine;
Long had he sought her, and through many a soyle
So stood he still long gazing thereupon,
With sight whereof soone cloyd, and long deluded
And long while after, whilest him list remaine,
Long time had lou'd, and hop'd her loue to gaine,
That this of all his labour and long paine
For he through long and perfect industry,
The fruite of ioy and blisse, though long time dearely bought.
Thus Calidore continu'd there long time,
Whose sundry parts were here too long to tell:
And standing long astonished in spright,
Long time, as fit occasion forth them led;
And ioyed long in close felicity:
That enuies louers long prosperity,
Which with the rest they tooke not long agoe,
And wrought so well with labour and long paine,
Their Captaine long withstood, & did her death forstall.
Knowing his voice although not heard long sin,
Like him that being long in tempest tost,
Her gentle hart, that now long season past
And life to feele, that long for death had sought;
So long till all the entry was with bodies mand.
Whereof she long had lackt the wishfull sight,
That long had lyen dead, and made againe aliue.
Which they from many long had robd and rent,
Right so it fares with me in this long way,
For all that hetherto hath long delayd
Thus long continu'd Claribell a thrall,
And liued long in peace and loue entyre,
Long since had fought in field. Als Claribell
Seeing her weake and wan, through durance long.
Of his first quest, which he had long forlore;
The which the Faery Queene had long afore
Was that same infant, which so long sith past
My liefe (sayd she) ye know, that long ygo,
She long so held, and softly weeping sayd;
And art thou yet aliue, whom dead I long did faine.
Tho wondring long at those so straunge euents,
Which hauing thought long dead, she fyndes aliue,
After that he had labourd long in vaine,
And thereunto a great long chaine he tight,
As if he learned had obedience long,
So did he eeke long after this remaine,
Albe that long time after Calidore,
O welcome child, whom I haue longd to see,
Which long'd to Angela, the Saxon Queene,
For life she him enuyde, and long'd reuenge to see.
His forces faile, ne can no longer fight.
He would no longer stay him to aduize,
To draw them longer out, and better twine,
Her list no longer in that place abide;
Her hand fell downe, and would no longer hold
No longer space thereto he did desire,
That his faint foe no longer could abide
He could no longer beare, but forth issewed,
And bore him quite out of his saddle, longer
The morrow next, ne gaue him longer day;
When as the Carle no longer could sustaine,
And to her said; Dame be no longer sad:
Ne yet Mathusalem, though longest liu'd;
The forlorne mayd did with loues longing burne,
